data.title: Bert Berns song composer
data.meta_description: Posts about Bert Berns song composer written by craigr244
data.text:
A Little Bit of Soap & a Lot of Hits!

craigr244

Bert Russell Song Writer Extraordinaire!

Bert Russell came to my attention with while working on my McCoys post recently – The song that kicked off the McCoys career, “Hang On Sloopy” was co-written by Russell along with Wes Farrell.

But long before hitting it with the song first recorded by the Vibrations, Russell had already made his mark on the nation’s charts.

Bert Russell was born Bertrand Russell Berns on November 8, 1929 – like Farrell – in New York City – the Bronx to be exact. Russell was inspired by the music of immigrant Cubans and found his was to the island before the revolution took place.

Upon his return he would do a bee-line to join the ‘Brill Building’ genre of young composers who congregated at the 1650 Broadway address – more or less finding the actual Brill at 1619 Broadway off-limits to the young crowd.

Berns recorded with a few groups in his early years including “The Kings of Twist” and a group called “The Mustangs” that was actually Berns with his sometimes writing partner Wes Farrell.

After several tries with his song pen – Russell would hit it big with the Jarmels “Little Bit of Soap” which placed him firmly on the song writing map!

He took a shot a recording as well doing so as “Russell Byrd” – He made one appearance on the Hot 100 with his song “You’d Better Come Home” in 1961.

Bert didn’t do too bad with another ditty, “Twist and Shout” big for the Isley Brothers and also big for the Fab Four. Berns would go to Atlantic Records as a producer replacing Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller as staff producer!

1964 saw Bert’s Keetch record label kick off with a single by Linda Laurie “Jose He Say”. That was a short-lived venture with only three releases – the others by the Mustangs and one by the Pussycats.

Laurie had given us the rather strange “Ambrose Part 5” in 1958. I posted some time ago that Linda – just out of high school – provided the entire vocal narrative on Ambrose – including the seemingly deep male voice repeating “Just Keep Walking”.

Bert was comfortable composing both lyrics and the music but worked along the way with many talented song writers:

Phil Medley (A Million to One – Jimmy Charles)

Bob Elgin (A Hundred Pounds of Clay – Gene McDaniels)

Norman Meade (Time Is On My Side – The Rolling Stones)

Wes Farrell (Hang On Sloopy – The McCoys)

Jerry Wexler (Honey Love – The Drifters)

Mike Leander (Lady Godiva – Peter & Gordon)

Bob Feldman (What’s Gonna Happen When Summer’s Done – Freddy Cannon)

Jerry Goldstein (My Boyfriend’s Back – The Angels)

Richard Gottehrer (Night Time – The Strangeloves)

Jeff Barry (Be My Baby – The Ronettes)

Leiber and Stoller (Kansas City -Wilbert Harrison)

In 1965 Berns would give it another go, starting up the record label “BANG” which took the initials of it’s four founders, Bert Berns, Ahmet Ertegun, Nesuhi Ertegun and Gerald Wexler. Berns would assume complete control of BANG.

Because of his love of rhythm and blues, Berns would also start up Shout Records and would sign Freddie Scott, Erma Franklin, Donald Height, The Exciters, Deon Jackson, Jackie Moore and in 1970 the Equals from Great Britain.

A motion picture documentary was produced on Bern’s life in 2016 titled “BANG! The Bert Berns Story”

Bert Russell was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2016 awarded the Ahmet Ertegun Lifetime Achievement Award.

Russell accomplished so much for such a tragically short lifetime – passing away at age 38 on December 30th, 1967 – It is hard to imagine what he might have left for all of us! More than two dozen songs from Russell’s pen charted after his death!

Twistin’ & Shoutin’

craigr244

Bert Berns

Bert was born November 8th, 1929 Bertrand Russell Berns in the Bronx, New York.

He only lived for 38 years but during that time more than left his mark as a top-notch song composer. He began his career as a mambo dancer first in New York and then in neighboring Cuba before that country headed in another direction politically.

Bertrand returned to the United States and found his way into the famed “Brill Building” at 1650 Broadway working as a song composer at a salary of $50 a week. It wasn’t long before the move to composer paid dividends. A young group of singers out of Richmond, Virginia would record “A Little Big of Soap” which was released in July of 1961 by Roulette Records.

The song would go to number 12 on the Hot 100 and number 7 and the R&B charts giving the Jarmels their only charting single

Then, in August of 1961, another Berns’ composition fell into the hands of producer Phil Spector. Atlantic Records’ brought a young duo into the studio, “The Top Notes” who were Derek Ray and Howard Guyton. Berns was present during the recording session and was aghast at the results. This was not one of Spector’s shining moments.

Spector completely altered a good hunk of the song and thus, “Twist and Shout” would go nowhere for Atlantic and Berns. Later Atlantic Records’ executive Jerry Wexler admitted that he should have trusted the still-young Russell with production duties.

As we all know – fortunately, in the summer of 1962, another upcoming group of singers from Ohio, “The Isley Brothers”, would enter the recording studio accompanied by Berns. The Isley’s were looking for something to get them back on track.

In the fall of 1959 they had landed near the middle of the Hot 100 with “Shout – Part 1” which reached a respectable number 47 on the pop charts – But it did not manage to catch the attention of the R&B market. The Isley’s weren’t especially confident in the song’s potential – especially since it originally was slated to be assigned as the “B” side to Jerry Butler’s “Make It Easy On Yourself”.

Much to everyone’s delight the song roared into the Top 20 of the Hot 100 reaching number 17 and gave the Isley Brothers their first R&B hit, going all the way to number 2!

“Twist and Shout” firmly established Bert Berns as a composer to be respected. Although his health would cast a dark cloud over the time he had remaining, he left his mark. Wexler would bring him into the Atlantic stable as their staff producer in 1963, replacing the great team of Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller.

Berns proved himself able to adapt, composing hits during the British Invasion era for American artists and hits for the Invaders as well.

In 1965, Berns teamed up with three others to form the “BANG” record label – taking first initials of the four operatives to name the label: Burt – Ahmet (Ertegun) – Nesuhi (Ertegun) and Gerald (‘Jerry’ Wexler). A year later Berns would establish the Shout record label where he had R&B hits by Freddie Scott and Erma Franklin.

Bert Burns would succumb to a failing heart – resulting from rheumatic fever contacted as a child. He died on December 30th, 1967 at the very young age of 38. He entered the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2016. His life was honored in the off-Broadway production of “Piece of My Heart – The Bert Berns Story”.
